category_summary:
**Google DeepMind's Project Genie** dominated discussions as **Demis Hassabis** [unveiled the frontier world model](/?date=2026-01-30&category=social#item-237bea5a5319) creating playable interactive environments from text prompts in real-time‚Äînow available to G1 Ultra users. **Ethan Mollick** shared early access impressions noting a "huge leap in physics" but some remaining issues.

- **Anthropic** released an RCT study showing AI-assisted coding trades skill mastery for speed‚Äîengineers finished faster but scored 17% worse on comprehension tests, sparking debate about AI learning tradeoffs
- **Jeremy Howard** [explained why LLMs](/?date=2026-01-30&category=social#item-69b834bad97e) haven't achieved breakthrough scientific research, referencing fundamental limitations he identified 18 months ago
- **DeepMind's AlphaGenome** published in Nature with open weights drew significant attention from the genomics research community
- **xAI** [launched the **Grok Imagine API**](/?date=2026-01-30&category=social#item-ad9784e658fc) with fal partnership (5.8M views), while **Fran√ßois Chollet** [released the ARC-AGI-3 toolkit](/?date=2026-01-30&category=social#item-66fb96f0c9da) enabling frontier agent research
- Research findings [challenged multi-agent hype](/?date=2026-01-30&category=social#item-e48125275a09): communication overhead makes them less effective than sequential single agents for non-parallelizable tasks

items.content:
AI can make work faster, but a fear is that relying on it may make it harder to learn new skills on the job.

We ran an experiment with software engineers to learn more. Coding with AI led to a decrease in mastery‚Äîbut this depended on how people used it.

items.title:
Anthropic launched MCP Apps this week.

This enables a new class of applications using Generative UI...
items.content:
Anthropic launched MCP Apps this week.

This enables a new class of applications using Generative UI.

Here is the thing:

Chatbots are dumb. You can't build a serious application for humans without these:

‚Ä¢ Progress indicators
‚Ä¢ Status updates
‚Ä¢ Confirmations

UX is still important, and this new wave of "everything is a chatbot" is learning this lesson the hard way.

Generative UI will be the next big thing.

Agents must be part of the UI, not just the conversation.

People don't want to read a dump of text responses. Instead, we want agents to drive cards, tables, forms, progress indicators, and confirmation dialogs.

The agent decides intent. Your application will render it visually.

Think about it this way:

1. Your agent will express what UI should exist
2. Your frontend will decide how to render it

Here's how the pieces fit together:

1. The A2UI and MCP-UI specifications define what an agent wants to show. They're declarative descriptions of components, interactions, and how user input flows back to the agent.

2. AG-UI is the transport layer. It handles streaming updates, shared state between agent and frontend, tool calls, and bidirectional communication.

3. Your app still controls everything that matters: rendering, UX, permissions, safety.

This is the future of agentic applications.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Following yesterday's [News](/?date=2026-01-28&category=news#item-30b05edaef22) coverage, Analysis of Anthropic's MCP Apps launch and the rise of Generative UI. Argues chatbots alone are insufficient - agents need to drive UI elements (cards, tables, forms, progress indicators). Explains A2UI, MCP-UI specs and AG-UI transport layer.
items.reasoning: Substantive technical analysis of emerging agent UI paradigm. Connects multiple specifications (A2UI, MCP-UI, AG-UI) into coherent vision. Good engagement (82 likes) on timely topic.

items.title: The founder started Primesense (I was the first to bring you that, which turned into the 3D sensor i...
items.content:
The founder started Primesense (I was the first to bring you that, which turned into the 3D sensor in the front of your iPhone). After I interviewed Aviad Maizels, who started that company, Apple bought it. He's a smart dude who sees the world in 3D.

This is an important purchase for Apple because later this year it will introduce a new kind of camera.

In two years everyone will have a camera, headphones, and glasses that all work together joined by the iPhone.

items.title: Last August, we previewed Genie 3: a general-purpose world model that turns a single text prompt int...
items.content:
Last August, we previewed Genie 3: a general-purpose world model that turns a single text prompt into a dynamic, interactive environment. Since then, trusted testers have taken it further than we ever imagined ‚Äî experimenting, exploring, and pioneering entirely new interactive worlds. Now, it‚Äôs your turn. 

Starting today, we're rolling out access to Project Genie for Google AI Ultra subscribers in the U.S. (18+). We know what you create will be out of this world üöÄ

items.title: One of the best ways to contribute directly to the current frontier of AI research is to build agent...
items.content:
One of the best ways to contribute directly to the current frontier of AI research is to build agents that can solve ARC-AGI-3 environments with human-level efficiency.

Today we're releasing a toolkit that lets you interact with all public environments locally, at 2000 FPS.

You can run your first game with a super simple Python script (see our docs), and you can watch your agent interact with the environment in real-time.

items.title:
#PaperADay 13
2020: DREAM TO CONTROL: LEARNING BEHAVIORS BY LATENT IMAGINATION
https://t.co/FbStuzbG...
items.content:
#PaperADay 13
2020: DREAM TO CONTROL: LEARNING BEHAVIORS BY LATENT IMAGINATION
https://t.co/FbStuzbGFH

More than doubled the performance of PlaNet, and beat the state-of-the-art model-free algorithm of the day that used many more environment steps.

PlaNet (#PaperADay 12) wasn‚Äôt really a reinforcement learning algorithm ‚Äì it learned to predict which states would get a reward, but it didn‚Äôt learn how to get more of them. If it was possible to get rewards inside the planning horizon of some dozens of steps, it could often find them, but the behavior was often ‚Äúshortsighted‚Äù. There were several tasks where PlaNet didn‚Äôt do any better than random at an action repeat of 2, because it took more than a couple seconds of behavior to score. They crutched around it by using larger action repeats on those tasks in the original paper, but re-ran them all with a fixed action repeat in the tables here.

Traditional RL algorithms like Q learning and SARSA can propagate rewards far back in time using temporal difference learning and state or action value functions.

Dreamer basically adds traditional RL policy and value functions for the latent states, and learns them strictly in the imagined state transitions instead of from the online real environment interactions. This allows long term credit assignment like the model-free agents, but exploration can still happen in imaginary traces without having to test them in the environment (which can sometimes be misleading).

Some of their terminology confused me for a bit relative to other RL papers: What they call an ‚Äúaction model‚Äù I expected to be called a ‚Äúpolicy model‚Äù (although action model might be better terminology!), and they predict a ‚Äúdiscount factor‚Äù as a measure of the chance of an episode terminating, but discount factor usually refers to the exponential gamma factor in target bootstrap calculations.

They do a TD-lambda style weighting of all the possible imagined trajectory lengths to get their bootstrap targets, and they do stochastic backpropagation through the entire imagined trajectory to account for the stochastic action model decisions.

For learning the world dynamics models (in real experience, not in imagination), they predict latent-to-latent, but the loss is the pixel reconstruction from the predicted latent to the real observation. They experimented with contrastive estimation and pure reward prediction, but pixel reconstruction is simplest and worked best. It is basically like an autoencoder across multiple latent steps before going back to pixels.

The policy model is a little unusual: ‚ÄúThe action model outputs a tanh mean scaled by a factor of 5 and a softplus standard deviation for the Normal distribution that is then transformed using tanh (Haarnoja et al., 2018). The scaling factor allows the agent to saturate the action distribution.‚Äù

In addition to the continuous control tasks from PlaNet, they also test on a subset of discrete control tasks from Atari and DMLab. I always smile at the use of the DeepMind Lab (DMLab) benchmarks, which were built on Quake 3, but with all the violence removed. These more complex tasks only use an imagination horizon of 10 instead of 50, presumably because the model was counterproductively bad beyond that horizon.
items.author: @ID_AA_Carmack
items.summary: John Carmack's #PaperADay 13 - detailed technical analysis of the 2020 Dreamer paper on model-based reinforcement learning, explaining how it doubled PlaNet performance by adding policy and value functions learned in imagined state transitions
items.reasoning: Exceptional technical depth from legendary programmer John Carmack. Educational value for RL practitioners. His paper review series provides accessible explanations of important ML papers.

Dreamer basically adds traditional RL policy and value functions for the latent states, and learns them strictly in the imagined state transitions instead of from the online real environment interactions. This allows long term credit assignment like the model-free agents, but exploration can still happen in imaginary traces without having to test them in the environment (which can sometimes be misleading).

Some of their terminology confused me for a bit relative to other RL papers: What they call an ‚Äúaction model‚Äù I expected to be called a ‚Äúpolicy model‚Äù (although action model might be better terminology!), and they predict a ‚Äúdiscount factor‚Äù as a measure of the chance of an episode terminating, but discount factor usually refers to the exponential gamma factor in target bootstrap calculations.

They do a TD-lambda style weighting of all the possible imagined trajectory lengths to get their bootstrap targets, and they do stochastic backpropagation through the entire imagined trajectory to account for the stochastic action model decisions.

For learning the world dynamics models (in real experience, not in imagination), they predict latent-to-latent, but the loss is the pixel reconstruction from the predicted latent to the real observation. They experimented with contrastive estimation and pure reward prediction, but pixel reconstruction is simplest and worked best. It is basically like an autoencoder across multiple latent steps before going back to pixels.

The policy model is a little unusual: ‚ÄúThe action model outputs a tanh mean scaled by a factor of 5 and a softplus standard deviation for the Normal distribution that is then transformed using tanh (Haarnoja et al., 2018). The scaling factor allows the agent to saturate the action distribution.‚Äù

In addition to the continuous control tasks from PlaNet, they also test on a subset of discrete control tasks from Atari and DMLab. I always smile at the use of the DeepMind Lab (DMLab) benchmarks, which were built on Quake 3, but with all the violence removed. These more complex tasks only use an imagination horizon of 10 instead of 50, presumably because the model was counterproductively bad beyond that horizon.

items.title: guys, i'm still on the @claudeai cowork hype train. if you are not using this for a routine knowledg...
items.content:
guys, i'm still on the @claudeai cowork hype train. if you are not using this for a routine knowledge work task once a day you are probably miscalibrated for HOW MUCH BETTER THIS THING IS compared to Anthropic's initial Computer Use demo. 

in this task i had Cowork:
- scan my files for 4 zoom video recordings
- WATCH the videos (read selected video images)
- OPEN UP YOUTUBE  to the right channel
- UPLOAD the videos for me
- TITLE the videos and add description (they were "good enough")
- TRIM the silences from the zoom recording (it can click and drag!)
- drive autonomously a 9 stage plan until completion.

i like that i was able to interject and change plans midway as i underspecified some things. it also respected my instructions to pause for my manual inspection for irreversible tasks. this thing is a powerhouse for non-coding computer work and if you haven't tried you are genuinely probably behind.
items.author: @swyx
items.summary: swyx provides enthusiastic firsthand review of Claude's Cowork feature - used it to scan files, watch videos, upload to YouTube, trim silences, and execute 9-stage autonomous plan with mid-course corrections.
items.reasoning: Detailed practical use case from credible AI commentator showing computer use capabilities. 61K views and specific workflow details make this valuable signal.

items.title:
Powerpoint is dead - the Claude app itself is quite good at generating presentations. 

My presentat...
items.content:
Powerpoint is dead - the Claude app itself is quite good at generating presentations. 

My presentation generator agent is basically the same thing (it wraps Claude Agent SDK) BUT it adds a few quality of life enhancements: 

1. You can directly edit the generated text without having to retrigger a prompt. 
2. You can specify a "style" template and have the final powerpoint be rendered with similar colors/formatting
3. You get higher-accuracy context because we use LlamaParse under the hood.

Also this is an open-source app.

Check it out! 

Repo: https://t.co/sAUnl2HBur
App: https://t.co/cgvmMnS6tG
Sign up to LlamaParse/LlamaCloud: https://t.co/XYZmx5TFz8

items.title:
üìàIn October, we opened ForecastBench, our AI forecasting benchmark, to external submissions. 

Here'...
items.content:
üìàIn October, we opened ForecastBench, our AI forecasting benchmark, to external submissions. 

Here's how the top two teams approached the benchmark:

‚Ä¢ @xai: Minimal scaffolding: give Grok 4.20 (Preview) the question, web/X search, Python REPL, average 8 forecasts

‚Ä¢ @cassi: Multi-stage pipeline: split to sub-questions, retrieval, model ensemble (o3 + GPT-5), crowd adjustment

Both are tied at #2 on our leaderboard, behind only superforecasters, and outperforming our baseline LLM runs.
items.author: @Research_FRI
items.summary: ForecastBench results show xAI's Grok 4.20 (Preview) and cassi team tied at #2 on AI forecasting leaderboard, behind only superforecasters. xAI used minimal scaffolding while cassi used multi-stage pipeline with o3 + GPT-5
items.reasoning: Important benchmark results showing Grok 4.20 performance vs other frontier models, with specific architectural approaches compared
items.summary_html: ForecastBench results show xAI's Grok 4.20 (Preview) and cassi team tied at #2 on AI forecasting leaderboard, behind only superforecasters. xAI used minimal scaffolding while cassi used multi-stage pipeline with o3 + GPT-5
items.content_html:
üìàIn October, we opened ForecastBench, our AI forecasting benchmark, to external submissions.

Here's how the top two teams approached the benchmark:

‚Ä¢ @xai: Minimal scaffolding: give Grok 4.20 (Preview) the question, web/X search, Python REPL, average 8 forecasts

‚Ä¢ @cassi: Multi-stage pipeline: split to sub-questions, retrieval, model ensemble (o3 + GPT-5), crowd adjustment

Both are tied at #2 on our leaderboard, behind only superforecasters, and outperforming our baseline LLM runs.

items.title: ICML, one of the prestigious conferences in AI, has received more than 30,000 submissions this year....
items.content:
ICML, one of the prestigious conferences in AI, has received more than 30,000 submissions this year. 

When AI can write and rewrite papers, expect this number to grow even more in the upcoming years.

No one has the capacity to peer review this volume, so inevitably AI will be used to review these papers.

The quality of research will inevitably go down.

items.title: Reviewing insurance claims is historically a deeply manual task: claims packets are usually a staple...
items.content:
Reviewing insurance claims is historically a deeply manual task: claims packets are usually a stapled collection of various docs, from accident reports, police reports, to medical bills and legal filings

Thanks to LLMs/VLMs, we‚Äôve massively increased the accuracy automating claims intake through agentic reasoning.

Thanks to our recent release, we‚Äôve also made *building* these workflows super easy too!

With our new LlamaAgents builder, you can describe in English a workflow that can classify and extract different claims documents depending on their type. Check out the video below. 

Check it out: https://t.co/XYZmx5TFz8
Our release blog: https://t.co/JYM7ra0UKX

items.title:
I built https://t.co/4rAUTXjAhc to help me stay-up-date with new AI stuff.

It's tracking 14K open s...
items.content:
I built https://t.co/4rAUTXjAhc to help me stay-up-date with new AI stuff.

It's tracking 14K open source repos so far, with contributions from over 145K developers.

Every day, it:
- searches for new AI repos (based on 123 keywords and topics)
- surfaces repos that are gaining traction, and
- categorizes each repo

The annotations are done by AI so they are not super accurate, but they've helped me find some useful stuff.

It also lets me see where the contributors are, so when I travel, I can find folks doing cool stuff in a new city or country.

items.title: I was biased to be excited about this paper, however the multiagent setup (well documented) is disap...
items.content:
I was biased to be excited about this paper, however the multiagent setup (well documented) is disappointing in its creativity. 

Paper would have you believe that multiagents are bad on ‚Äúsequential tasks like planning‚Äù (plancraft). but because only simple aggregation was done, or the orchestrator was dumb, we dont know if multiagent rollouts were used to explore plans before committing to them. this should be robust to error amplification and in fact is a core thesis of how DeepThink has a performance boost over Thinking. was this work done in consult w the same team as gdm deepthink? probably not?

I cant find a github repo so ofc substantive discussion ends here. disappointing.
items.author: @swyx
items.summary: swyx critiques a multiagent research paper, arguing the simple aggregation methods don't properly test multiagent rollouts for planning tasks. Notes lack of GitHub repo limits discussion.
items.reasoning: Technical critique of research methodology from informed commentator. Highlights gap between paper claims and actual multiagent potential.
items.summary_html: swyx critiques a multiagent research paper, arguing the simple aggregation methods don't properly test multiagent rollouts for planning tasks. Notes lack of GitHub repo limits discussion.
items.content_html:
I was biased to be excited about this paper, however the multiagent setup (well documented) is disappointing in its creativity.

Paper would have you believe that multiagents are bad on ‚Äúsequential tasks like planning‚Äù (plancraft). but because only simple aggregation was done, or the orchestrator was dumb, we dont know if multiagent rollouts were used to explore plans before committing to them. this should be robust to error amplification and in fact is a core thesis of how DeepThink has a performance boost over Thinking. was this work done in consult w the same team as gdm deepthink? probably not?

I cant find a github repo so ofc substantive discussion ends here. disappointing.

items.title: Clawdbot (I guess, Moltbot now) is the bleeding edge of the bleeding edge of what's possible with ag...
items.content:
Clawdbot (I guess, Moltbot now) is the bleeding edge of the bleeding edge of what's possible with agents right now.

But I can't recommend that people use it with their emails and accounts unless they truly know what they are doing.

It‚Äôs like handing C to someone who just started learning programming and expecting them not to corrupt memory.

This appears to be an alternative for people who want a safe version of a super agent.

Lots of power + low risk.

items.title: Important research on "disempowerment": when we hand the reins of our lives over to agents against o...
items.content:
Important research on "disempowerment": when we hand the reins of our lives over to agents against our beliefs or better judgement. It's cool that they did this and released the research.

Weirdly the thing I focused on here is that they considered disempowerment "irrelevant" in coding conversations. Not quite sure why giving up all power to the LLM is not a concern in coding?
https://t.co/SJ0hF6CiRL

items.content:
This post is great, there's lessons and lessons in here. What I took away:
- Evals were key for getting to best performance
- Prompt optimization matters!
- Tool use is still not as reliable as we need it to be
- Product docs need to be agent-friendly

https://t.co/Sc1zn6QXvQ

This post is great, there's lessons and lessons in here. What I took away:

  • Evals were key for getting to best performance
  • Prompt optimization matters!
  • Tool use is still not as reliable as we need it to be
  • Product docs need to be agent-friendly

https://t.co/Sc1zn6QXvQ

Most vision AI systems don‚Äôt fail in production because they‚Äôre inaccurate.

They fail because the p...
items.content:
Most vision AI systems don‚Äôt fail in production because they‚Äôre inaccurate.

They fail because the pipeline is a mess.

The biggest hidden culprit?
Post-processing that adds latency, breaks exports, and behaves differently on every device.

This is exactly the problem I explore how @ultralytics is tackling a new architectural shift.

Let‚Äôs dig in.

#UltralyticsPartner

You might be wondering... How does Project Genie work?ü§î 

Great question. 

Project Genie is a proto...
items.content:
You might be wondering... How does Project Genie work?ü§î 

Great question. 

Project Genie is a prototype web app powered by several of our most advanced AI models, each bringing a unique capability to the equation. From Genie 3's ability to simulate the physics and interactions of any scenario, to Nano Banana's sketching and design, to Gemini's advanced world knowledge and reasoning, this combination results in Project Genie's unique, interactive, (and really cool) user experience. 

But don't just take our word for it, try it today at: https://t.co/peuMPRcnLL

items.summary: Google AI explains Project Genie's multi-model architecture: Genie 3 for physics/interactions, Nano Banana for sketching, Gemini for reasoning.

items.content_html:
You might be wondering... How does Project Genie work?ü§î

Great question.

Project Genie is a prototype web app powered by several of our most advanced AI models, each bringing a unique capability to the equation. From Genie 3's ability to simulate the physics and interactions of any scenario, to Nano Banana's sketching and design, to Gemini's advanced world knowledge and reasoning, this combination results in Project Genie's unique, interactive, (and really cool) user experience.

But don't just take our word for it, try it today at: https://t.co/peuMPRcnLL

@allergictohype From what I hear internally, Apple is going to have trouble getting into humanoid robots because they're very concerned about the safety of those things. 

But Apple does what Apple does: it comes in late and then redefines the space that it's in. That said, there's a lot of plays that happen before humanoid robots get into all of our homes, no matter what Elon says.

items.title: Lead creator of Claude Code, Boris Cherny, responds to OpenAI co-founder Andrej Karpathy's thoughts ...
items.content:
Lead creator of Claude Code, Boris Cherny, responds to OpenAI co-founder Andrej Karpathy's thoughts on coding with AI:

- Andrej now does 80% AI coding and 20% manual edits.
- Boris is at 100% AI and hasn't written manual code in months.

- Andrej watches the AI "like a hawk" in a traditional IDE to catch errors.
- Boris trusts it enough to ship code from Slack or his phone.

- Andrej worries about a "Slopacolypse" of bloated, inefficient code in 2026.
- Boris bets the models (like Opus 4.5) will become smart enough to clean up their own mess.

- Andrej uses AI to loop until it passes tests.
- Boris uses AI to review its own code before shipping.

What's your take on the current state of AI coding? Do you trust AI to write 100% of your code.
items.author: @AlphaSignalAI
items.summary: Alpha Signal AI summarizes debate between Boris Cherny (Claude Code creator) and Andrej Karpathy on AI coding: Boris at 100% AI coding vs Karpathy at 80%, different views on trust and code quality.
items.reasoning: Useful summary of notable expert disagreement on AI coding practices, though secondhand.
items.summary_html: Alpha Signal AI summarizes debate between Boris Cherny (Claude Code creator) and Andrej Karpathy on AI coding: Boris at 100% AI coding vs Karpathy at 80%, different views on trust and code quality.
items.content_html:
Lead creator of Claude Code, Boris Cherny, responds to OpenAI co-founder Andrej Karpathy's thoughts on coding with AI:

  • Andrej now does 80% AI coding and 20% manual edits.
  • Boris is at 100% AI and hasn't written manual code in months.
  • Andrej watches the AI "like a hawk" in a traditional IDE to catch errors.
  • Boris trusts it enough to ship code from Slack or his phone.
  • Andrej worries about a "Slopacolypse" of bloated, inefficient code in 2026.
  • Boris bets the models (like Opus 4.5) will become smart enough to clean up their own mess.
  • Andrej uses AI to loop until it passes tests.
  • Boris uses AI to review its own code before shipping.

What's your take on the current state of AI coding? Do you trust AI to write 100% of your code.

items.title: The software engineers have been anal about code maintainability and structure because they knew tha...
items.content:
The software engineers have been anal about code maintainability and structure because they knew that they would have to read and fix this code at some point in the future.

When AI writes and fixes the code, it can be as messy (from the human software engineer's anal point of view) as it could be, and this wouldn't matter because no human would have to read and fix this code at some point in the future.

Leave machine commands to the machine to write and fix. Do a human thing: make decisions under uncertainty.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov argues code maintainability concerns become irrelevant when AI writes/fixes code - humans won't read it, so it can be 'messy', humans should focus on decisions under uncertainty
items.reasoning: Provocative and controversial perspective on future of software engineering, sparks debate (80 replies, 29k views)

items.title:
Building software has always been about planning and verification.

I think that's what many people ...
items.content:
Building software has always been about planning and verification.

I think that's what many people miss.

Coding has always been secondary.

Coding is fun, it took time, and required training, but it was never the most important aspect of building software.

AI didn't change what matters. It just made it obvious that coding was never the bottleneck.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago argues that planning and verification have always been the core of software development, not coding - AI just made this obvious by removing the coding bottleneck
items.reasoning: Thoughtful perspective on how AI changes software development from recognized educator. Relevant to ongoing discourse about AI and programming

items.content:
‚ú® Okay I went a bit crazy and also spoofed the DNS for altavista(.)com

And then I rebuilt the homepage with Claude Code based on screenshots of it because I couldn't even find an actual HTML source of it anymore (not even on WaybackMachine)

First it wrote it in <div>'s but old browser don't support those, so then I asked it to change it to a <table> layout

I filled it up with the Top 100 Hacker News blogs and some other links, search also works of course!

So now after 27 years AltaVista is active again, at least on https://t.co/M1hEUBAynC üòä

items.content: Generally I find people who are anti-AI because they think AI is just hype respond rather well to being shown how AI works in a non-judgmental way.  And if they hate AI for other moral reasons, they may still dislike AI after but they become more informed critics & we need those.

items.title: Hey coders and computational scientists! If you have never implemented Genetic Algorithms for your s...
items.content:
Hey coders and computational scientists! If you have never implemented Genetic Algorithms for your simulation, parameter search, and optimization problems & challenges, then you have really missed out. Get this book. I used GAs in my galaxy collisions simulation research as a Research Astrophysicist. I was hooked immediately ‚Äî GAs are incredibly clever and efficient for some NP-hard problems. But you don't need a PhD to benefit. You need this book.

Hands-On Genetic Algorithms with #Python ‚Äî Apply genetic algorithms to solve real-world #AI and #MachineLearning problems [2nd Edition]: https://t.co/sr5D96zQO4 v/ @PacktDataML

ùìöùìÆùîÇ ùìïùìÆùì™ùìΩùìæùìªùìÆùìº:
üîµLearn how to implement genetic algorithms using Python libraries DEAP, scikit-learn, and NumPy.
üü¢Take advantage of cloud computing technology to increase the performance of your solutions.
üü†Discover bio-inspired algorithms such as particle swarm optimization (PSO).

items.title: The bad situation right now is the big critics who pretend AI is fake and give cover to whole groups...
items.content:
The bad situation right now is the big critics who pretend AI is fake and give cover to whole groups of people to ignore AI, rather than actually participating in the policy & social processes of shaping AI use

There is a lot to criticize and respond to, but being informed helps

items.title: With my experience and everything I know, I could come to any mostly white-collar company, talk to p...
items.content:
With my experience and everything I know, I could come to any mostly white-collar company, talk to people about what their job tasks are, and architect a way to replace some of those tasks with AI, saving between 20% and 35% of costs to the employer or increasing productivity by the same amount.

I could do that, but knowing how simple it is today, I feel zero motivation to do that.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: burkov reflects that despite ability to architect AI solutions saving 20-35% costs for any white-collar company, he feels no motivation because it's become too simple.
items.reasoning: Personal reflection from ML author on commoditization of AI consulting work.
items.summary_html: burkov reflects that despite ability to architect AI solutions saving 20-35% costs for any white-collar company, he feels no motivation because it's become too simple.
items.content_html:
With my experience and everything I know, I could come to any mostly white-collar company, talk to people about what their job tasks are, and architect a way to replace some of those tasks with AI, saving between 20% and 35% of costs to the employer or increasing productivity by the same amount.

I could do that, but knowing how simple it is today, I feel zero motivation to do that.

items.title: This NIPS 2007 paper is a foundation of the Netflix Prize: The PMF model was a breakthrough in the N...
items.content:
This NIPS 2007 paper is a foundation of the Netflix Prize: The PMF model was a breakthrough in the Netflix Prize competition, helping teams achieve nearly a 7% improvement over Netflix's baseline Cinematch system.

With thousands of citations, it is considered one of the most influential papers in the history of collaborative filtering and recommender systems.

The principles introduced in the paper‚Äîscaling linearly with observations and handling sparse datasets‚Äîbecame the standard architecture for production-scale recommendation engines at companies like Netflix and Amazon.

Read with an AI tutor: https://t.co/NFG7r0tlAW

Read alone: https://t.co/rwzmuNx56M
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov explains NIPS 2007 PMF paper's influence on Netflix Prize and recommender systems - introduced scalable collaborative filtering principles
items.reasoning: Educational content on foundational ML research, provides historical context
items.summary_html: Burkov explains NIPS 2007 PMF paper's influence on Netflix Prize and recommender systems - introduced scalable collaborative filtering principles
items.content_html:
This NIPS 2007 paper is a foundation of the Netflix Prize: The PMF model was a breakthrough in the Netflix Prize competition, helping teams achieve nearly a 7% improvement over Netflix's baseline Cinematch system.

With thousands of citations, it is considered one of the most influential papers in the history of collaborative filtering and recommender systems.

The principles introduced in the paper‚Äîscaling linearly with observations and handling sparse datasets‚Äîbecame the standard architecture for production-scale recommendation engines at companies like Netflix and Amazon.

items.title: Nikola Tesla was a brilliant engineer and innovator. Born in present day Croatia, he studied enginee...
items.content: Nikola Tesla was a brilliant engineer and innovator. Born in present day Croatia, he studied engineering and physics, but never finished his degree. He emigrated to the US, briefly worked for Edison, but then struck out on his own. The vast majority of his most impactful innovation and work was accomplished in the 1890s, over the course of just one decade. After that he was never able to obtain the kind of funding that his projects required, and his innovations were increasingly zany and out of step with the mainstream electrical engineering practice. Amongst other reasons, in the late 1800s Maxwell‚Äôs equations became well established, and we could design increasingly complex electrical contraptions using analytical and mathematical principles to guide us. Those were not Tesla‚Äôs strengths. He had an incredible, preternatural even, intuition and power of visualization that verged on hallucinations. In the wild west of the early electrical engineering practice those gifts had served him well. But those were exceptional times where exceptional geniuses could flourish, never to obtain again. Tesla died alone, penurious, and largely forgotten in a small New York City hotel room in the 1940s.
items.author: @tunguz
items.summary: Tunguz reflects on Nikola Tesla's career trajectory - brilliant innovator whose intuitive methods became obsolete as engineering became more mathematical/analytical, dying forgotten
items.reasoning: Thoughtful historical analysis with implicit parallels to AI industry - how exceptional individual intuition may be displaced by systematic approaches. Good engagement from credible author.
items.summary_html: Tunguz reflects on Nikola Tesla's career trajectory - brilliant innovator whose intuitive methods became obsolete as engineering became more mathematical/analytical, dying forgotten
items.content_html: Nikola Tesla was a brilliant engineer and innovator. Born in present day Croatia, he studied engineering and physics, but never finished his degree. He emigrated to the US, briefly worked for Edison, but then struck out on his own. The vast majority of his most impactful innovation and work was accomplished in the 1890s, over the course of just one decade. After that he was never able to obtain the kind of funding that his projects required, and his innovations were increasingly zany and out of step with the mainstream electrical engineering practice. Amongst other reasons, in the late 1800s Maxwell‚Äôs equations became well established, and we could design increasingly complex electrical contraptions using analytical and mathematical principles to guide us. Those were not Tesla‚Äôs strengths. He had an incredible, preternatural even, intuition and power of visualization that verged on hallucinations. In the wild west of the early electrical engineering practice those gifts had served him well. But those were exceptional times where exceptional geniuses could flourish, never to obtain again. Tesla died alone, penurious, and largely forgotten in a small New York City hotel room in the 1940s.

items.title:
Is your #ERP helping you scale or holding you back?

At @Acumatica Summit this week, I spoke with Ni...
items.content:
Is your #ERP helping you scale or holding you back?

At @Acumatica Summit this week, I spoke with Nick Novy, CEO of @Korpack_Inc, about growth, ERP, and what it takes for mid-sized companies to create value at speed.

Korpack‚Äôs growth journey from startup to multi-location contract packing leader mirrors what I see daily: companies don‚Äôt need more technology, they need better visibility, flexibility, and decision velocity.

We talked BI, customer transparency, AI, and why legacy systems limit scale long before leaders realize it.
If you‚Äôre a mid-sized leader navigating growth and tech change, this story may resonate.

üëâ Watch our full conversation here: https://t.co/j6XbZheYa8

#SMB #CloudERP #AI #Innovation #AcumaticaSummit

items.title:
@lreyzin There's a few other confounding factors:
- this is submitted PDFs, not yet papers entering ...
items.content:
@lreyzin There's a few other confounding factors:
- this is submitted PDFs, not yet papers entering review 
- ICML doesn't require attendance from authors this year
- it's in South Korea so e.g. Chinese authors might be more able to attend (and thus submit)
items.author: @thegautamkamath
items.summary: Gautam Kamath notes confounding factors in ICML submission numbers: PDFs not papers, no attendance requirement, South Korea location may affect Chinese author submissions
items.reasoning: Useful context on ML conference dynamics from academic researcher
items.summary_html: Gautam Kamath notes confounding factors in ICML submission numbers: PDFs not papers, no attendance requirement, South Korea location may affect Chinese author submissions
items.content_html:
@lreyzin There's a few other confounding factors:

  • this is submitted PDFs, not yet papers entering review
  • ICML doesn't require attendance from authors this year
  • it's in South Korea so e.g. Chinese authors might be more able to attend (and thus submit)

items.title: @flashlabsdotai Clawdbot (I guess, Moltbot now) is the bleeding edge of the bleeding edge of what's ...
items.content:
@flashlabsdotai Clawdbot (I guess, Moltbot now) is the bleeding edge of the bleeding edge of what's possible with agents right now.

But I can't recommend that people use it with their emails and accounts unless they truly know what they are doing.

It‚Äôs like handing C to someone who just started learning programming and expecting them not to corrupt memory.

This appears to be an alternative for people who want a safe version of a super agent.

Lots of power + low risk.

items.title: Lots of folks have been asking for this for a while, but we wanted to wait until TOML support in the...
items.content:
Lots of folks have been asking for this for a while, but we wanted to wait until TOML support in the python stdlib was widely available. 3.11 added that support, and is pretty widely installed now.

(We install `tomli` to backfill support where needed.)

End-to-end models, built without post-processing, designed e...
items.content:
That‚Äôs the new standard for vision AI.

End-to-end models, built without post-processing, designed edge-first.

The result ‚Üí faster inference, simpler deployment, predictable behavior, and up to 43% faster CPU performance.

This is why Ultralytics YOLO26 is a real inflection point for production vision systems.

items.title:
One step causes more production pain than almost anything else:
Filtering overlapping detections aft...
items.content:
One step causes more production pain than almost anything else:
Filtering overlapping detections after inference.

That single step ‚Üí

‚Üí Adds latency
‚Üí Complicates exports
‚Üí Creates unpredictable behavior across hardware

Now imagine removing it entirely.
One clean, end-to-end inference pass.
No clean-up logic. No fragile thresholds.

items.title:
Here‚Äôs the uncomfortable truth I keep seeing in real deployments:

Vision pipelines collapse under c...
items.content:
Here‚Äôs the uncomfortable truth I keep seeing in real deployments:

Vision pipelines collapse under complexity, not model quality.

‚Üí Extra post-processing logic
‚Üí Heuristic thresholds no one wants to maintain
‚Üí Different behavior on GPU vs CPU vs edge

Accuracy looks great in a demo.
Production exposes everything else.

items.content_html:
Here‚Äôs the uncomfortable truth I keep seeing in real deployments:

Vision pipelines collapse under complexity, not model quality.

‚Üí Extra post-processing logic

‚Üí Heuristic thresholds no one wants to maintain

‚Üí Different behavior on GPU vs CPU vs edge

Accuracy looks great in a demo.

Production exposes everything else.

items.title:
The underrated part is flexibility at scale.

One agent can cover multiple roles:

‚Üí Sales
‚Üí Support...
items.content:
The underrated part is flexibility at scale.

One agent can cover multiple roles:

‚Üí Sales
‚Üí Support
‚Üí Marketing
‚Üí Operations

Configured through templates and brand language.
Deployed across web, WhatsApp, mobile, and voice.
Integrated directly with CRMs, calendars, and payments.

This is how AI becomes a teammate, not a tool.

items.title:
Most chatbots are capped by design.

They answer questions.
They follow scripts.
They wait for human...
items.content:
Most chatbots are capped by design.

They answer questions.
They follow scripts.
They wait for humans to act.

AI agents flip that model.

‚Üí They understand intent
‚Üí Adapt to context
‚Üí Take initiative without being prompted

That‚Äôs the leap most teams underestimate.

items.title:
@bassbasedrk I totally believe you (about the power plant).

> Have you worked on a project with mor...
items.content:
@bassbasedrk I totally believe you (about the power plant).

> Have you worked on a project with more than 100 people across teams that wasn't outsourced to cheap Ukrainian devs a decade ago?

Of course, on many of them. The design of software is done in advance by defining the interfaces of all modules and then implementing these modules by different small teams or individual developers in parallel.

Today you replace a small team/developer working on a module with a developer instructing AI to develop a module, and nothing changes for the rest of the process.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov describes software design with defined interfaces allowing parallel development by teams - AI replaces small teams working on modules
items.reasoning: Practical perspective on AI in software development process
items.summary_html: Burkov describes software design with defined interfaces allowing parallel development by teams - AI replaces small teams working on modules
items.content_html:
@bassbasedrk I totally believe you (about the power plant).

> Have you worked on a project with more than 100 people across teams that wasn't outsourced to cheap Ukrainian devs a decade ago?

Of course, on many of them. The design of software is done in advance by defining the interfaces of all modules and then implementing these modules by different small teams or individual developers in parallel.

Today you replace a small team/developer working on a module with a developer instructing AI to develop a module, and nothing changes for the rest of the process.

items.title: @adithyavis It's hard to reduce it to something unique. I guess I'm motivated by "cracking" the syst...
items.content:
@adithyavis It's hard to reduce it to something unique. I guess I'm motivated by "cracking" the system. The system (the world in which we are living) rejects everything you try to put into it‚Äîit's built this way‚Äîso when something it put into it sticks, this excites me.

But it's not that simple. I could become a baker and it would technically "stick." But I need it to be something very few people can do.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: burkov reflects on motivation - likes 'cracking the system' and doing things few can do.
items.reasoning: Personal reflection tangentially related to AI work.

@adithyavis It's hard to reduce it to something unique. I guess I'm motivated by "cracking" the system. The system (the world in which we are living) rejects everything you try to put into it‚Äîit's built this way‚Äîso when something it put into it sticks, this excites me.

But it's not that simple. I could become a baker and it would technically "stick." But I need it to be something very few people can do.
